awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Oxygen transport and the evolution of high-altitude adaptation in humans
awd_abstract_narration:
Several human populations, each with distinct histories, have adapted to harsh high-altitude environments over the course of thousands of years. This doctoral dissertation research project compares the physiologies of two high-altitude populations and assesses the extent to which they have adapted similarly or differently to the same environmental stressor – low oxygen. Using the same methods, measured in populations thousands of miles apart at the same elevation thousands of feet above sea level, the project takes a new approach by measuring how high-altitude adaptations work in people during physical activity. The results of the research build on a large body of previous research on this topic and provide important information about how the high-altitude adaptations in both populations have contributed to their survival over time in low-oxygen environments. The project investigators provide scientific outreach among a local community and incorporate feedback and ideas from study participants into the project. This project also provides training for undergraduate and graduate students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines.

Some highland populations have resided in hypoxic environments for thousands of years, promoting stable evolutionary changes in aspects of their biology related to oxygen transport and delivery. Though exposed to the same selective pressure, these populations exhibit some distinct physiological adaptations, suggesting that certain historical contingencies have shaped different trajectories of trait evolution across geographic space and time. The overall objective of this project is to compare the mechanisms of improved oxygen delivery at high altitude. The central hypothesis that this study tests is that one population improves oxygen delivery primarily through increased blood oxygen content, while the other improves oxygen delivery primarily through increased blood flow. Using refined and carefully matched protocols, this project employs exercise testing, respiratory gas analysis, and hematological measurements in 70 individuals from each population to test this hypothesis. The results of this research contribute to a large body of research on human biological variation in relationship to environmental stressors, importantly through the added perspective of oxygen delivery during the stress of physical activity at high-altitude.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant has allowed Ph.D. candidate Taylor Harman to complete research for her dissertation, titled “Evolution on High: An exploration of the distinct evolutionary trajectories of two native high altitude populations, and the narrative representations of their physiologies.” Over the course of the funding period, Harman performed fieldwork in the highland Khumbu valley of Nepal, working with a local indigenous population known as Sherpas. The goal of the research was to perform a very carefully controlled comparison between two indigenous high-altitude groups: the Sherpas of the Himalayas, and the Quechuas of the Andes.

This comparison was proposed as a way to critically reevaluate a longstanding hypothesis in the discipline, which suggested that populations from the Andes versus the Himalayas have adapted to high altitude environments very differently, and further, that Himalayans were “better” adapted than Andeans. Harman successfully collected a wide array of physiological data in 70 Himalayan Sherpa participants, and created a matching dataset with a group of 300 Andean Quechua participants. This has been the largest sample size used for such a comparison, and one of few studies to use identical protocols and equipment. Harman found, generally speaking, that Sherpas and Quechuas had very similar physiological responses to high altitude. This finding has challenged the conventional wisdom of the discipline, and suggests that the characterization of Andeans as “maladapted” was ill informed. Further, this work reasserts the importance of replicating scientific findings to ensure that they are robust.

Beyond collecting physiological data, Harman also collected detailed field notes and conducted interviews with Sherpa participants. This work was performed in an effort to understand how Sherpas understood themselves both culturally and biologically. Generally, scientific narratives are solely controlled by scientists. However, as an anthropologist, Harman found it important to incorporate indigenous self-conceptions into her work as a way to let Sherpas tell their own stories. Ultimately, she found that Sherpas’ self-perceptions were far more nuanced and varied than the typical narrative of Sherpa “strength” that tends to be perpetuated in scientific and popular writings.

Harman’s dissertation will incorporate both the physiological and ethnographic portions of her research. To be completed in 2024, her interdisciplinary dissertation will provide robust new evidence with regard to a recent branch of human evolution, and attempt to engage in critical self-reflection of the scientific process.
